channel.description: Recent content in Vectors on jverkamp.com

item.title: Authorship attribution: Part 3
item.description:
So far, we’ve had three different ideas for figuring out the author of an unknown paper (top n word ordering in Part 1Â andÂ stop word frequency / 4-grams in Part 2). Here’s something interesting though from the comments on the Programming Praxis post:

GlobulesÂ said July 19, 2013 at 12:29 PM Patrick Juola has aÂ guest post on Language LogÂ describing the approach he took.

item.title: Authorship attribution: Part 2
item.description: Last time, we used word rank to try to figure out who could possibly have written Cuckoo’s calling. It didn’t work out so well, but we at least have a nice framework in place. So perhaps we can try a few more ways of turning entire novels into a few numbers.

item.title: Authorship attribution: Part 1
item.description: About two weeks ago, the new crime fiction novel Cuckoo’s CallingÂ was revealed to have actually been written by J.K. Rowling under the pseudonym Robert Galbraith. What’s interesting is exactly how they came to that conclusion. Here’s a quote from Time magazine (via Programming Praxis):

item.title: Ludum Dare 26 - VTanks - Results
item.description: The voting period for Ludum Dare 26 has ended, which means that now we have some results! Before I post my own,Â take a moment to check out the overall leaders. Given that there wereÂ 2346 games submitted (1610 in the compo and 736 in the jam), there are bound to be some real gems in there.

item.title: VTanks for Ludum Dare 26
item.description:
So when I got home, I decided that I really didn’t want to miss another Ludum Dare. Granted, there was only about two hours left in the competition. I’m good, but I’m not that good. ðŸ˜„

Also, I really wanted to make a web-based game, which meant either write another game in Java (suboptimal) or learn how to write a game in Flash orÂ JavaScript. Nothing like a last minuteÂ decisionÂ to use an unfamiliar framework and write a game in less than 24 hours. ðŸ˜„

In the end, I did it in six.
